title: Badgerys Creek airport announcement leaves Daily Telegraph feeling unloved

Badgery's Creek: little noise, no rail Homeowners in western Sydney will not need to insulate against noise from Sydney's new airport, according to a draft plan and environmental statement released by the government.
PT1M41S 620 349 One of the hallmarks of Tony Abbott's government was its close relationship with Sydney's conservative Daily Telegraph newspaper and hostility to a broad cross-section of other media outlets.
So when Malcolm Turnbull took over, Liberal strategists promised a new approach to media relations, including a policy of no longer playing favourites and fewer "drops", also known as a government pre-briefing on a specific "announceable" or new policy.
And over the weekend, that policy was put into practice after Deputy Prime Minister Warren Truss gave western Sydney MPs a secret briefing on the draft airport plan and the draft environmental impact statement for Sydney's Badgerys Creek airport last Wednesday.
A new approach to the media was promised when Malcolm Turnbull became Prime Minister. Photo: Andrew Meares
Fairfax Media has been told that some MPs raised objections in a meeting between Mr Truss and Liberal MPs including Paul Fletcher, John Alexander, Alex Hawke, Fiona Scott, Russell Matheson, Nickolas Varvaris, Craig Kelly and Louise Markus about the newspaper being dropped the story ahead of time.
Advertisement Mr Truss, whom one participant in the meeting described as an "old-school politician, that's not his style", gave an undertaking to hold the announcement until Monday.
But the decision did not please the hard-driving editor of the Telegraph , Paul "Boris" Whittaker.
Warren Truss received praise for keeping his word. Photo: Robert Shakespeare
​So over the weekend, Whittaker texted Mr Turnbull to request a rethink on the media blackout on the story.
As another Liberal source who was kindly disposed to the newspaper put it, "they basically think of it as the Daily Telegraph airport".
The Prime Minister obviously took the request seriously.
"They basically think of it as the Daily Telegraph airport", a Liberal source said of the newspaper.
Staff in his office hit the phones, calling back the MPs who attended Wednesday's meeting and asking them to reconsider their position.
Wasn't this a "special case" because the paper had been such a strong advocate for the airport?
Some Liberals were willing to reconsider the decision, but in the end, nothing changed — the newspaper would miss out, and on Monday Mr Turnbull's office respected the wishes of the backbench, having seen first hand what can happen to a leader who does otherwise. Mr Truss and his colleagues duly made the announcement.
So why did some MPs object to the seemingly innocuous pre-briefing, which had been such a feature of the former Abbott government's media playbook?
As one Liberal MP put it, in the dying days of the Abbott government, Liberals grew fed up with learning about new government policies and initiatives that affected them and their voters in the Abbott regime's favourite mouthpiece.
When controversial changes to citizenship laws were published in the newspaper before being approved by the cabinet, Mr Abbott was hit by a devastatingly detailed series of leaks from his cabinet .
"The era of pre-briefing without consent from or consultation with MPs is coming to an end. It got to be too much, policy announced in the Tele , and most of the colleagues got sick of it".
Another colleague praised Mr Truss for keeping his word, and the Prime Minister's office for respecting the wishes of the backbench.
"The Tele has to understand it backed the wrong horse [Tony Abbott] and it won't always get its way from now on," one MP said.
